Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: In this project students transferring into Colorado State University from community colleges in a regional alliance are given scholarships for their last two years of study in one of the STEM disciplines. Alliance institutions are heavily Hispanic in the ethnicity of their students, drawn from the local community. This project is unusually sensitive to informing the students and their families of the opportunities at CSU. In each new cohort of eight transfer students, the Rocky Mountain Scholars Program provides not only financial aid but support for the academic and social transition to the university. An existing Center for Undergraduate Research provides research opportunities and academic support. Two graduate students are trained to serve as mentors to the students. The ultimate goal of the project is to identify talented students among a population underrepresented in academic science and provide the support needed to encourage them to persevere in their education. Some of them ultimately will become professors for the next generation; all will enhance their communities with their ability to contribute with the skills of STEM.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Rocky Mountain Scholars Program (RMSP) at Colorado State University emphasizes the recruitment and success of underrepresented minorities in STEM disciplines. Eighty-six students have participated in this program. Of those, 59 have graduated with STEM degrees, 25 are still active in the program pursuing STEM degrees (since the end of the program's funding period, it has been maintained with institutional funding), only 1 switched to a non-STEM major and, consequently, left the program, and 1 transferred into a STEM program at another university.

To date, participants in this program have a 100% rate of retention in higher education and a 98.84% rate of persistence in STEM programs. These rates are dramatically higher than our institutional averages. Of the 59 participants who have graduated, 54 (92%) have either elected to pursue a STEM graduate degree or have entered the STEM workforce.

Almost three dozen RMSP scholars were authors/co-authors on peer reviewed manuscripts over the past five years and over half presented at research symposia. Among those, six participants earned 1st Place at the Regional Engineering Days Symposium, ten earned highest honors at the Regional Research Symposium, four received 1st Place at a National Research Event, eight were honored at an International Research Showcase in Mexico, and six were recognized at both the national and international level for their participation in the International Genetically Engineered Machines Competition. One of the graduate students was awarded first place at the Regional Research Symposium and was also awarded first place at the Regional Venture Showcase.  

Overall, the Intellectual Merits of this project included the creation of a unique scholarship program in the Rocky Mountain region that supported a diverse population of students in STEM disciplines, with an emphasis on intensive research projects in advanced settings.  Outcomes from these projects have been disseminated in peer-reviewed journals, presented at several national and international STEM education conferences, and four diversity conferences. Acknowledgement of participant support was cited in almost three dozen journal articles.

The Broader Impacts of this S-STEM Project were built upon an existing infrastructure to identify and nurture, within the community college pipeline, cohorts of high-ability, traditionally underserved STEM undergraduates, who, with mentoring provided in the Rocky Mountain Scholars Program, will transition into future faculty members and/or leaders in STEM industry. The research findings of this program have been widely disseminated for the broad benefit of STEM educators throughout the nation.
